Tim

In Great Britain the police have been arresting children for playing with toy guns. Natalie and Darren, both 12, were arrested for playing with a toy gun. The UK police fingerprinted them and then threw them in a jail cell.
 http://news.bbc.co.uk/cbbcnews/hi/uk/newsid_2198000/2198387.stm 
 
 In US airports similar things are happening. "Security officers at Los Angeles Airport have confiscated a gun in a security scare - from a plastic toy soldier. The two-inch weapon belonged to a GI Joe toy - similar to an Action Man."
 http://www.sky.com/skynews/article/0,,30200-12070123,00.html
JFriday

Would you feel safer if toy guns were taken away and children playing games were treated like criminals. The Airline Security thing also seems to laed to my POV. I am sure that everyone on that flight were made a lot safer becuase G.I. Joe was disarmed. Why didnt they arrest G.I. Joe for trying to haul a weapon on board the plane? This idea has had no hand in doing anything good what so ever. Name one incedent that you would like to see common place here in America. I honestly think that the security official who did that was stupid, oh and 40% of fake bombs and weapons get through during routine test but thank God that they stopped that gun-toting G.I. Joe. That is a load off.
 
 <UnGodly ammounts of Sarcasm<

 But the real reason behind the toy gun ban in the UK is the repression of "anti-social" people. They have laws againist "anti-social" people.

 The reason for the anti-social behivor is common street thugs no longer have any fear of unarmed people.
 
 What is worse, the anti-social laws are being applied to people who voice political disssent. If you voice a non-constructive opinion of the government, you can be labeled "anti-social".
 
 The ultimate for of political correctness:

 I am proud to be an American.
kelvin90701

My personal philosophy:
 
 I do not have any kids, if I did I would never let them play with toy guns. If other people want their kids to play with them, fine, but mine never will. Toy guns confuse small children and confuse reality and play. I do not want my small children to equate play with real firearms.
 
 I'd rather give them a real firearm and teach them how the have fun under supervison and how to manage themselves when they are around a firearm with no supervision. I would want kids to find an adult or aviod a firearm with no supervision.
 
 But for heavens sake, they do not need to be against the law.
BlindOne

Kelvin if your kids are unable to tell the difference between a toy and the real steel then they shouldn't be allowed outside the house, all replica guns have to have a orange painted tip in order to be shipped into the US, now is it harmful for a kid to go 'BANG' at a friend?? I mean come on, what's going to happen someone get shot in the head with a plastic dart? Now UK allows replica guns in their country without the orange tip, if you ever heard of airsoft then you would know that UK is pretty big into it, now these guns are exact replicas, only difference is they shoot harmless plastic BBs. Now teaching a child how to use a real gun may make him think he's allowed to use one when he wants, and that may get him killed or a friend killed

 It is none of your business how other people raise their children.

Sorry, but it is open to debate I never closed it. This is a challenge to YOU to justify your interference in how other people raise thier own children.
 
 Toy guncontrol the ultimate insult to personal responsibility as given in the example with the orginal post. It is the state deciding how YOU should raise your children.
 
 "Kelvin if your kids are unable to tell the difference between a toy and the real steel then they shouldn't be allowed outside the house"
 
 Sounds like a lecture or a willingness to interve in my personal business to me.
voiceofreason

Originally posted by kelvin90701 
 
 Toy guncontrol the ultimate insult to personal responsibility as given in the example with the orginal post. 
 
 I think you got it backwards Kelvin. You're the one that said you wouldn't let your children play with toy guns because you're afraid that your children wouldn't be able to tell the difference between a real gun and a toy gun. Blindone never advocated toy gun-control. On the contrary, Blindone was pointing out that toy guns don't harm children.
 
 And if your children can't tell the difference between fantasy and reality how do you expect them to handle a gun responsibly? They might try to shoot the boogey man or their own shadow.
JFriday

Perhaps you should pay more attention, he said small children, I myself have never encountered a kid that did not know the difference between the two that was old enough to be playing cops and robbers, I think he was refering only to young children.
JFriday

I believe once again, it has been taken out of context, he would teach them how to use a firearm, you make it sound like he would just let them keep a loaded shotgun under their beds. I am sure that what he meant was that he was going to steer clear of toy guns until they were old enough to tell the difference and educate them on real ones.
kelvin90701

Originally posted by voiceofreason 
 I think you got it backwards Kelvin. 
 
 
 I will not let my kids play with toy guns. I don't want them to think guns of any type toy or otherwise are for play. I don't want them to associate killing people as play.
 
 At the same time I would not make the same judgement for other people and how they raise their own.
 
 When I old enough to start getting interested in guns, my father gave me a .357 magnum. I remember getting scared by the blast. Dad even says I even cried, but I don't remember that, but the lesson was learned. Firearms are not for play. Killing people is not for play.
 
 TOY GUNS DO HARM CHILDREN, but that is not for the government or other people to decide. If you want to raise your children to be killers, fine that is your business. Mine will learn to defend themselves and respect life.
BlindOne

sorry man but letting a small child play with a toy gun won't harm them. If they are old enough to play with a toy gun they are old enough to be told that it's not real and if you see a gun not to touch it, I mean I was taught that when I was 3 for christ sake, and guess what, I haven't seen a gun without the owner like 2 feet away since, now I understand that you are afraid your kid may find a gun and play with it.
 
 Now if you are afraid of your kid picking up a gun and playing with it then dude you need to get rid of everything small in your house, not let them watch TV, get rid of everything sharp (they might think they are a ninja) and so forth, cause everything can be considered a toy. When I have kids I will let them play with toy guns, but nothing that looks too real. Haven't you ever played guns?
JFriday

I believe that for small children they are innappropriate, but then again, I cant raise your kids and I dont want to, that is your job, but if I do have kids (God help me then) I will wait to introduce them to toy guns until they are old enough to know the difference.
